force.name: Northumbria Police
force.pledge:
The police service in England and Wales will support law abiding citizens and pursue criminals relentlessly to keep you and your neighbourhoods safe from harm.

We will:

Treat you fairly, with respect and provide accessible services when you need them.


Tell you who your Neighbourhood Policing Team is and how you can contact them.


Ensure police patrols in your area are where and when you say you need them most.


Respond promptly to all messages to your Neighbourhood Policing Team.


Attend emergencies immediately, giving an estimated arrival time.


Answer non-emergency calls promptly and provide a policing response to meet your needs.


Arrange regular public meetings with your Neighbourhood Policing Team to discuss those things important to you.


Provide monthly updates about what we are doing with our partners to make your neighbourhood safer.


Agree with victims how often we will update you about your case and for how long.


Respond promptly to any report of poor service and agree how it will be handled.


We want to do our best for you. If we fail to meet our Policing Pledge we will always explain why we have not met the high standards we aim for and you deserve.

team.name: Jarrow and Hebburn
team.description: Home of the Great North Run, the largest town in the area is South Shields. South Tyneside's population is largely centred around the riverside towns of Jarrow and Hebburn. Our primary police base for the area is Millbank.

location.address: Hebburn Police Station Victoria Road East Hebburn NE31 1YG

priority.issue: Anti-Social Behaviour within Hebburn Riverside including the Marina
priority.action:
Patrols are carried out by both police and Council Neighbourhood Responders on a regular basis and include Project Shield patrols in hot spot areas.
We continue to use all available powers, including dispersal notices, arrests, stop and search, prosecution for public spaces protection order, seizure of intoxicating substances, tenancy action visits and closure order notices initiated by the Council and the police.
Police and South Tyneside Council jointly make parent/guardian home visits of those involved in the disorder.
Youth justice services are used for those young people arrested, with a view to changing behaviours and longer-term problem solving through diversionary services.
The Local authority continues to provide diversionary services and engagement at peak times. There has been a 41% reduction in incidents recorded from Jan-Jun 2025 against the same period in 2024.

priority.issue: Shop theft
priority.action:
We have initiated changes into shop theft protocols, implemented further resourcing to tackle this ongoing crime trend, targeted prolific offenders, obtained Community Behaviour Orders on shop theft nominals and continue to progress others. Since October 2024 South Tyneside Area command have seen offenders sentenced by the courts to over 10 years’ worth of custodial sentences linked to prolific offenders.
Northumbria Police and South Tyneside Council are determined to maintain that commitment to tackle crime and disorder. This has seen a reduction in retail related crimes in the whole of Jarrow and Hebburn.
Morrisons within the Viking Centre has historically been the store that has the highest number of retail crimes reported over a number of months. This issue was identified and a problem solving plan devised in February 2025, with simple but effective actions. Since the POP plan was implemented we have achieved, in one particular month, just over a 70% reduction in retail thefts. The team has built relationships with the staff at the store, engaged with security staff regarding quality of evidence and methods of reporting.

priority.issue: Anti-Social Behaviour in Wallsend Town Centre and Wallsend Metro. Focus on individuals causing disorder while intoxicated.
priority.action: Neighbourhood team concentrated on working with off licence retailers to educate them around sales of alcohol to intoxicated customers. We've been issuing Community Protection Notices to individuals loitering and begging in the town centre. NPT worked in partnership with the local authority to obtain a Closure Order, which was granted against an address linked to ASB in the area that then led to reduced complaints.

priority.issue: Motorcycle crime and disorder in Wallsend, Howdon and Battle Hill
priority.action:
We have introduced Op Apollo as a response to reports of motorcycle theft and anti-social Behaviour associated with off road unregistered vehicles.
Neighbourhood officers have worked with the burglary team to identify suspects responsible for the theft of motorcycles across the area, which has led to arrests of several suspects and the recovery of stolen vehicles. NPT have further targeted addresses linked to motorbike ASB with vehicles identified and seized for road traffic offences.

priority.issue: Retail crime and shoplifting in Battle Hill and Wallsend Town Centre
priority.action: Officers carried out engagement with retailers to improve reporting. Then targeted named prolific offenders, using stop and search powers to recover stolen property, capturing evidence using new technology to quickly gather CCTV evidence. This resulted in the successful prosecutions of identified suspects with outcomes including custodial sentences, community orders and fines.

priority.issue: Residential burglaries and vehicle crime
priority.action: Neighbourhood officers have worked alongside the burglary investigation team to identify suspects involved in a series of break-ins and vehicle thefts across the area. This has resulted in several arrests and the recovery of stolen property. NPT have further targeted addresses linked to vehicle crime, with stolen vehicles recovered and multiple seizures made for Road Traffic Offences.

priority.issue: Anti-social behaviour
priority.action:
Focus on early identification, problem solving, partnership working, and proactive patrols, with a specific emphasis on motorcycle-related disorder across the whole borough.
Neighbourhood officers have conducted high-visibility patrols in ASB hotspot areas, particularly targeting locations affected by off-road motorcycle disorder. Working alongside partner agencies and local communities, officers have identified key individuals involved in persistent ASB and motorcycle nuisance.
Several vehicles have been seized for road traffic offences, and tenancy warnings have been issued where appropriate. Engagement with youth services and local housing providers has supported longer-term problem-solving approaches. Op Apollo has been introduced to support this priority. A reduction in ASB has been recorded already with measures in place to continue this downward trend.

priority.issue: Shop theft in Killingworth Shopping Centre and Forrest Hall
priority.action:
Neighbourhood officers have utilised stop/search powers to target known prolific offenders and have worked in partnership with local businesses and retail security to gather intelligence and support prosecutions.
Several Criminal Behaviour Orders have been pursued against repeat offenders, and joint operations with partner agencies have led to multiple arrests and a visible reduction in offending in key retail areas. Op Paradise, which is a North Tyneside initiative, is utilised to focus on this priority. There have been numerous positive outcomes and sentences with further tactics being implemented to continue with this positive action.

priority.issue: Youth related anti-social behaviour in Morpeth bus station and town centre
priority.action: We have worked together with community safety officers and local schools to effectively target those involved in ASB, with both enforcement and engagement. A diversion programme, Beyond the Ball, is designed to dissuade young people from involvement in anti-social bejaviour.. We have also worked with Asset Watch, who provide the town centre CCTV systems, to gather evidence of any reported issues and identify those involved. As a result, there has been a 63% reduction in reports made to the police relating to youth involved ASB since Jan 2025.

priority.issue: Retail crime
priority.action: Following a rise in shoplifting offences in Morpeth, we have made several arrests of offenders and issued community protection warnings. The introduction of Shopwatch radio handsets has enabled retailers to have direct contact with officers, allowing a quicker response. As well as more visible foot patrols, we've used a new tool to help us more efficiently obtain CCTV footage for investigations. The new technology has led to the identification of offenders and provided us with further evidence. There has been a 48% reduction in shoplifting reports since Jan 2025 vs previous year.

priority.issue: Night-time economy anti-social behaviour
priority.action:
Footfall within local night-time economy has increased and as a result we have seen a rise in alcohol related anti-social behaviour. To address the issues, neighbourhood team shift patterns have been changed to a later finish time to give an increased presence during peak visitor hours.
We've been carrying out visits to local bars, pubs and clubs, to ensure licence holders are acting responsibly and in line with their licence.
We take enforcement action against offenders through both criminal and civil approaches, banning individuals causing issues through the Pubwatch scheme.
We have worked with partners to improve the town centre CCTV, giving us better quality evidence and improved identification rate of offenders. The above has led to a 26% reduction in reported incidents along with a 7% decrease in violent crime.

location.address: Newcastle City Centre Police Station Forth Banks Newcastle upon Tyne NE1 3PH

priority.issue: Prevent and deter sexual offending within the night time economy
priority.action:
Our Friday and Saturday night time economy plan means you will see uniformed officer presence across the city centre, in the areas of highest footfall. As part of Operation Cloak, uniformed officers are deployed to prevent and deter sexual offending. Whilst plain clothes officers patrol and observe for any suspicious or concerning behaviour, intervening early to prevent any offending taking place. Operation Salus focuses on vehicles within the night time economy, to prevent any inappropriate use or vehicles being located in areas which could be mistaken for a taxi.
All officers are briefed before deployment and are present to observe for signs of any vulnerability and offer immediate safeguarding. Our Safe Haven van is parked every Friday and Saturday night from 10pm – 4am in the Bigg Market, staffed by uniformed officers. Medical assistance is also available next to the Safe Haven.

priority.issue: Anti-Social Behaviour around Monument, Blackett Street and Bewick Court
priority.action: With increased footfall to the city centre, we are tackling summer increases in ASB by conducting both uniformed and plain clothes patrols. We proportionately use our powers to disperse groups, issuing dispersal orders, and community protection warning notices to stop behaviour having a detrimental effect on residents and businesses in the area. As a result, we have seen a 20% reduction in reporting of ASB this year vs 2024.

priority.issue: Serious violence
priority.action: We have a proactive team, working under Operation Spear, dedicated to reducing serious violence in the city centre. As part of their role, they focus on early identification of key individuals and target offenders. We seek to remand in custody where appropriate and look at disruption through the use of conditions, Community Protect Warning Notices and Criminal Behaviour Orders or Injunctions. Through partners in City Safe we look to make early identification of people who would benefit from diversion and intervention to remove them from situations/environments which can lead criminality. Currently, as a year on year comparison, most serious violence has been reduced by 10%.

team.name: West Shields and Riverside
team.description: Home of the Great North Run, the largest town in the area is South Shields. South Tyneside's population is largely centred around the riverside towns of Jarrow and Hebburn. Our primary police base for the area is Millbank.

location.address: South Shields Police Station Millbank Station Road South Shields NE33 1RR

priority.issue: Anti-social behaviour within South Shields town centre including South Shields Interchange
priority.action:
Patrols are carried out by both police and Council Neighbourhood Responders on a regular basis and include Project Shield patrols in hot spot areas.
We continue to use all available powers, including dispersal notices, arrests, stop and search, prosecution for public spaces protection order, seizure of intoxicating substances, tenancy action visits and closure order notices initiated by the Council and the police.
Police and South Tyneside Council jointly make parent/guardian home visits of those involved in the disorder.
Youth justice services are used for those young people arrested, with a view to changing behaviours and longer-term problem solving through diversionary services.
The local authority continues to provide diversionary services and engagement at peak times.
In these areas, ASB has reduced by 45% from Jan-Jun 25 vs the same 6 months in 2024.

priority.issue: Anti-Social Behaviour within North and South Marine Park, Foreshore, Sea Front areas.
priority.action:
Patrols are carried out by both police and Council Neighbourhood Responders on a regular basis and include Project Shield patrols in hot spot areas.
We continue to use all available powers, including dispersal notices, arrests, stop and search, prosecution for public spaces protection order, seizure of intoxicating substances, tenancy action visits and closure order notices initiated by the Council and the police.
Police and South Tyneside Council jointly make parent/guardian home visits of those involved in the disorder.
Youth justice services are used for those young people arrested, with a view to changing behaviours and longer-term problem solving through diversionary services.
The Local authority continues to provide diversionary services and engagement at peak times.
Compared to the same 6 month period in 2024, Jan-Jun 2025 has seen North Marine Park 71% reduction in ASB incidents, South Marine Park 79% reduction in ASB incidents.

priority.issue: Shop theft
priority.action: South Tyneside Area Command have initiated changes into shop theft protocols, implemented further resourcing to tackle this ongoing crime trend, targeted prolific offenders, and obtained Community Behaviour Orders. Since October 2024 we have seen offenders sentenced by the courts to over 10 years’ worth of custodial sentences linked to prolific offenders.
